rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 (upbeat music)}
{\rtf1 So in this lab, we're going\par to be dealing with flow logs.}
{\rtf1 This could be bro conn logs,\par this could be Cisco Netflow.}
{\rtf1 This could be Jflow, Sflow, I don't care.}
{\rtf1 Basically, what we're doing is if we have}
{\rtf1 the limited metadata,\par source IP, source port,}
{\rtf1 dest IP, dest port, bytes, duration,}
{\rtf1 the flow-related fields.}
{\rtf1 What can we do to identify things?}
{\rtf1 To drive this home, we're\par going to actually have}
{\rtf1 multiple compromised\par systems in different ways,}
{\rtf1 so what we're going to do is\par identify three internal systems,}
{\rtf1 that are being controlled with encrypted}
{\rtf1 command and control, because\par encryption doesn't matter}
{\rtf1 to flow analysis, we're\par just looking at high level}
{\rtf1 metadata anyway, and we want to know}
{\rtf1 what three systems are they, and what port}
{\rtf1 are they being controlled from,\par which will give us an idea}
{\rtf1 of what application is being used.}
{\rtf1 Also, there's the kind\par of little bonus thing.}
{\rtf1 There's an internal user,\par that's doing something}
{\rtf1 to bypass internal controls,\par basically they want to be able}
{\rtf1 to access things that\par you otherwise would deny,}
{\rtf1 and we're going to find what\par system is he or she using,}
{\rtf1 and what application is likely being used.}
{\rtf1 We can't tell this with just flow data,}
{\rtf1 but we can make a really good inference,}
{\rtf1 and get really close to what\par likely is the application.}
{\rtf1 For example, port 80, probably HTDP.}
{\rtf1 That's what we're going to be doing.}
{\rtf1 So let's go ahead and dive into this.}
{\rtf1 So let's first start\par looking at the dashboard.}
{\rtf1 This is the four dot three\par dashboard, for Netflow.}
{\rtf1 For this, we've got a few\par things at our fingertips here.}
{\rtf1 We've got connections based on duration,}
{\rtf1 so this will chart out the IP addresses,}
{\rtf1 that have the longest running connections.}
{\rtf1 We have the host with\par the most bytes uploaded.}
{\rtf1 That's going to show systems}
{\rtf1 that are doing a lot of uploading.}
{\rtf1 Outbound connections by port,\par we've got the top talkers,}
{\rtf1 by the number of connection,\par so rather than total bytes,}
{\rtf1 it's the total number of connections,}
{\rtf1 and we have host with the\par most bytes downloaded.}
{\rtf1 So okay, let's start looking at this.}
{\rtf1 So if I want to figure\par out that systems are}
{\rtf1 being controlled, command and control,}
{\rtf1 one of the really good indicators to me,}
{\rtf1 is systems that have\par long running connections,}
{\rtf1 that are multiple hours, days, weeks old.}
{\rtf1 They just basically pen up\par a connection and stay there.}
{\rtf1 I want to know what those\par are, so if we look at this,}
{\rtf1 we've got one, nine, two,\par one, six, eight, one dot 50,}
{\rtf1 that's been up for 16,\par almost 17,000 seconds.}
{\rtf1 That's a very long time.}
{\rtf1 Below that, we have 10, five, 55, dot 21.}
{\rtf1 We also have this other\par guy, 10, zero, one dot four.}
{\rtf1 So we have multiple,\par long-running connections in here.}
{\rtf1 On top of this, one, nine, two,\par one, six, eight, one dot 50}
{\rtf1 shows up on multiple of these dashboards.}
{\rtf1 It's the system with\par the most bytes uploaded,}
{\rtf1 and it also shows up over,}
{\rtf1 show up on multiple these\par dashboards, over here,}
{\rtf1 most bytes downloaded, so most uploaded,}
{\rtf1 most downloaded, and\par longest-running connection.}
{\rtf1 That's a pretty good indicator.}
{\rtf1 So what we want to do\par now is start to zoom in,}
{\rtf1 and see what this is.}
{\rtf1 We also can see we have four dot 50,}
{\rtf1 which was one of the\par other systems in here.}
{\rtf1 That's got, just if we\par look straight at it,}
{\rtf1 four dot 50 is not a server system.}
{\rtf1 It's a client, it's doing port 53.}
{\rtf1 And it has a tremendously\par high Volm of DNS requests.}
{\rtf1 Now, four dot 50 did not show up on the,}
{\rtf1 on the long running\par duration, but it did show up}
{\rtf1 on the top talkers by\par volume of connections.}
{\rtf1 It was that fact, it's\par the largest by a lot.}
{\rtf1 So we have multiple things\par we're honing in on here.}
{\rtf1 We've got some indicators\par on long-running connections,}
{\rtf1 some which also showed\par up on the most uploaded,}
{\rtf1 most downloaded, and we\par have this four dot 50,}
{\rtf1 which also has the most\par number of connections.}
{\rtf1 Now, if I were to judge\par and say which one of these}
{\rtf1 is the most suspicious to\par me, I would jump on DNS.}
{\rtf1 The reason being a desktop, four dot 50,}
{\rtf1 should not be sending\par that many DNS requests,}
{\rtf1 especially compared to other systems.}
{\rtf1 Right below it, we see\par 10, five, 55, dot two.}
{\rtf1 That was the domain\par controller from previous labs.}
{\rtf1 So it is sending almost\par 40 times more logs,}
{\rtf1 than the actual DNS server\par in this environment.}
{\rtf1 This is highly indicative\par of DNS tunneling.}
{\rtf1 Extremely high volume of\par DNS, it's from a workstation}
{\rtf1 that shouldn't be sending that much,}
{\rtf1 and it's the top talkers,\par so very good sign}
{\rtf1 that four dot 50, right off the bat,}
{\rtf1 has command and control over DNS.}
{\rtf1 If we drill down into this\par more, just to prove this,}
{\rtf1 four dot 50, where are\par those connections too?}
{\rtf1 It's pretty much entirely\par out, external DNS,}
{\rtf1 and here's the system involved.}
{\rtf1 So, very good chance that's DNS tunneling.}
{\rtf1 Let's go ahead and exclude that system.}
{\rtf1 We're just going to treat\par that as compromised,}
{\rtf1 and next what we're going\par to do is flip to the next,}
{\rtf1 most likely system, to\par me that's one, nine, two,}
{\rtf1 one, six, eight, one dot 50, because it's}
{\rtf1 the most uploaded, most downloaded,}
{\rtf1 and has the longest-running connections,}
{\rtf1 so we're going to zoom in on that.}
{\rtf1 When we look at the ports involved here,}
{\rtf1 we see 40, 443, and 80 are involved,}
{\rtf1 and we see a few external IP addresses.}
{\rtf1 What I want to do now is scroll down,}
{\rtf1 and I want to see where that\par long-running connection is to.}
{\rtf1 In this case, we see it's to,}
{\rtf1 port 22, external, so\par that's interesting, alright.}
{\rtf1 So, that's the long-running connection.}
{\rtf1 That's really weird.}
{\rtf1 Let's see what else we can find here.}
{\rtf1 That's also where we got\par the bytes being involved.}
{\rtf1 And that is all to,}
{\rtf1 let me expand that for a second,}
{\rtf1 109, 78, 38 dot 11, so port 22}
{\rtf1 outbound probably shouldn't}
{\rtf1 be allowed anyway, hopefully\par in your environments,}
{\rtf1 you're blocking that, or it's\par only to authorized systems.}
{\rtf1 But we have large amount\par of upload and download,}
{\rtf1 and it's a report 22, so\par that is highly suspicious.}
{\rtf1 Let's keep going.}
{\rtf1 Alright, so if we get\par rid of one, nine, two,}
{\rtf1 one, six, eight, one dot 50, what's left?}
{\rtf1 Well, we still have 10, five, 55, 21.}
{\rtf1 It's got multiple connections in here.}
{\rtf1 We have two dot 50, which has\par an extremely long connection,}
{\rtf1 and we have one dot 81.}
{\rtf1 Basically, we have\par multiple systems in here,}
{\rtf1 that still have wrong,\par long-running connection.}
{\rtf1 The problem though is, the visualizations,}
{\rtf1 just looking for long-running connections,}
{\rtf1 it didn't say anything about\par whether they're external}
{\rtf1 or not, and if we're looking\par for command and control,}
{\rtf1 we're really looking for\par internal systems, reaching out}
{\rtf1 to an external system, so we're\par going to have to change things}
{\rtf1 up a little bit here,\par so what I'm going to do}
{\rtf1 is I'm going to add tags of external,}
{\rtf1 so again the top one here\par shows 10, five, 55 dot 21.}
{\rtf1 But really it's a bunch\par of smaller connections,}
{\rtf1 with one large one, let's see\par if it's actually external.}
{\rtf1 And we see it, we've got one,\par it's to four, four, three,}
{\rtf1 to a few external IPs, okay.}
{\rtf1 Let's keep going with that,\par so that one is roughly}
{\rtf1 30 minutes in length, that's not enough.}
{\rtf1 Really, what I want to see is\par something that's hours long,}
{\rtf1 so 18 hundred seconds divided by 60,}
{\rtf1 that's really about 30 minutes,}
{\rtf1 so its reaching outbound is\par 443, but it's only 30 minutes}
{\rtf1 in length, that's not\par enough for me to treat that}
{\rtf1 as suspicious, so I'm actually\par going to pop that back out,}
{\rtf1 and actually ignore that for a second,}
{\rtf1 'cause if we go back to this,\par there are still two systems}
{\rtf1 that have much longer\par DUR running connections.}
{\rtf1 This one is 18,000 seconds, 300 minutes,}
{\rtf1 or closer to like five hours.}
{\rtf1 And then we have 17 hundred seconds,}
{\rtf1 which is still pretty close, so two dot 50}
{\rtf1 and one dot 81, those to\par me are more suspicious.}
{\rtf1 So we go back, let's start\par looking at some of these.}
{\rtf1 Let's start with two dot\par 50, 'cause it's the most.}
{\rtf1 We look at the traffic here,\par we've got four, four, three}
{\rtf1 in port 80, but let's see where}
{\rtf1 the long-running connection is.}
{\rtf1 So we search at this, here it\par is, it's to this external IP.}
{\rtf1 We'll expand that.}
{\rtf1 See if there's any other information.}
{\rtf1 So for a Verizon Wireless ASM.}
{\rtf1 And that's about all we're seeing.}
{\rtf1 The other thing we could technically see,}
{\rtf1 but there's not enough data,\par is it's sending a little bit}
{\rtf1 more data to the server,\par than what it's receiving,}
{\rtf1 so one and a half, roughly to the server,}
{\rtf1 one to the download, that's\par not enough to make inference,}
{\rtf1 'cause this is really a,\par it's a really long-running}
{\rtf1 connection, that really\par hasn't sent much traffic,}
{\rtf1 so that's kind of unusual too.}
{\rtf1 If this was command and control,}
{\rtf1 it would occasionally say,\par do you have a task for me?}
{\rtf1 And the reply would be\par either nothing or no.}
{\rtf1 So this is where you might see\par more upload versus download,}
{\rtf1 but there's really not\par enough data to back that up.}
{\rtf1 All's we're seeing is a\par really long-running connection}
{\rtf1 to an external IP we haven't seen,}
{\rtf1 so there's a decent\par chance this also is victim}
{\rtf1 to command and control, or it's\par some type of vendor product}
{\rtf1 or something system we need to identify,}
{\rtf1 so we know that it makes\par long-running connections.}
{\rtf1 So right now, we got four\par dot 50, with DNS tunneling,}
{\rtf1 we got one dot 50, which looks\par like it has a long-running}
{\rtf1 connection, and is likely compromised,}
{\rtf1 and then we have two dot\par 50, which also makes it.}
{\rtf1 Let's back that out, and\par let's look at the next guy,}
{\rtf1 so one dot 81.}
{\rtf1 So, one dot 81.}
{\rtf1 Zoom in on that guy.}
{\rtf1 The ports involved are\par four, four, three 80,}
{\rtf1 and three, one, one, or three,\par one, three, three, seven,}
{\rtf1 which stands for ELE, it's\par kind of a hacker talk,}
{\rtf1 to make, sound like you're really cool.}
{\rtf1 The ELE destination port is\par the long-running connection,}
{\rtf1 so really likely chance\par that this one's compromised,}
{\rtf1 and that's the command control server.}
{\rtf1 Again, hopefully you're blocking\par outbound three, one, three,}
{\rtf1 three, seven, but this\par would be an indicator}
{\rtf1 of that activity, so DNS tunneling, yes.}
{\rtf1 Elite, yeah that's definitely,\par really likely points}
{\rtf1 to command and control,\par now there should have been}
{\rtf1 one more system with command and control,}
{\rtf1 and one system that is breaking policy.}
{\rtf1 My gut is, given the\par scenario, if we scroll up,}
{\rtf1 that two dot 50, is the\par other command and control,}
{\rtf1 has a long-running connection.}
{\rtf1 Then if we went back to one\par dot 50 and looked at it,}
{\rtf1 that box is the one that\par had a lot of download}
{\rtf1 and upload, and was using\par port 22, so it's connecting}
{\rtf1 outbound port 22, but it's\par downloading hundreds of gigs,}
{\rtf1 that is more indicative\par of someone bypassing}
{\rtf1 corporate control, to do\par things like watching videos.}
{\rtf1 Whether that's ESPN, or in this case,}
{\rtf1 I was streaming Netflix (laughs).}
{\rtf1 Or I'm sorry, YouTube,\par I was doing YouTube,}
{\rtf1 so four systems, three\par talking to encrypted command}
{\rtf1 and control, DNS, HTPS, and\par elite, and then we had bypassing}
{\rtf1 corporate policy over port\par 22, which is probably SSH.}
{\rtf1 So Netflow doesn't give\par us the complete picture,}
{\rtf1 but there's the decent\par amount of data in there,}
{\rtf1 that we can infer and make good guesses,}
{\rtf1 and even actually create\par alerts, so look for top talkers,}
{\rtf1 systems making lots of connections.}
{\rtf1 Maybe systems making few connections,}
{\rtf1 but they last forever,\par or look for large amounts}
{\rtf1 of upload or download activity.}
{\rtf1 Especially if something crosses all three,}
{\rtf1 signs point to you have a problem,}
{\rtf1 so collect Netflow, it's\par easy to get in your SIM,}
{\rtf1 and it's easy to analyze.}
